trans-unit.source: Provides data for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.RowCreated"></xref> and <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.RowDataBound"></xref> events.
Before the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control can be rendered, a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow> object must be created for each row in the control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.RowCreated> event is raised each time a row in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control is created.
This allows you to provide an event-handling method that performs a custom routine, such as adding custom content to a row, whenever this event occurs.
Similarly, each row in the control must be bound to a record in the data source before the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control can be rendered.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.RowDataBound> event is raised when a data row (represented by a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow> object) is bound to data in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control.
This allows you to provide an event-handling method that performs a custom routine, such as modifying the values of the data bound to the row, whenever this event occurs.
A GridViewRowEventArgs object is passed to the event-handling method, which allows you to access the properties of the row that raised the event.

To access a specific cell in the row, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableRow.Cells%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow> object contained in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRowEventArgs.Row%2A> property.

You can also determine which row type (header row, data row, and so on) is being created by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow.RowType%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow> object.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
For a list of initial property values for an instance of GridViewRowEventArgs, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRowEventArgs.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRowEventArgs"></xref> class.
Use this constructor to initialize a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRowEventArgs> class.
The following table shows the initial property value for an instance of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRowEventArgs>.

|Property|Initial value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRowEventArgs.Row%2A>|The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow> object contained in the `row` parameter.| > [!NOTE] > This constructor is used primarily by control developers when raising events.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow"></xref> object that represents the row being created or data-bound.
Gets the row being created or data-bound.
Use the Row property to access the properties of the row being created or data-bound.
To access a specific cell in the row, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableRow.Cells%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow> object contained in the Row property.

You can also determine which row type (header row, data row, and so on) is being created by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow.RowType%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow> object.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewRow"></xref> object that represents the row being created or data-bound.
